Award.AwardTitle: GP-GO: Building Latinx Pathways into Geoscience Graduate Education through R1-HSI-Nonprofit Collaborations

Division.LongName: Div of Res, Innovation, Synergies, & Edu

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will build pathways into geoscience (earth, oceanic, and atmospheric) for Latinx students through exposure to research opportunities, developing relationships with research active laboratories, and peer-to-peer mentoring. Efforts to enhance diversity must address systemic issues in order to ensure retention. The PIs seek to build a transferable, sustainable model for enhancing Latinx participation and retention in geoscience through collaboration – based in deep trust and equality – between Michigan State University (MSU; research university), Northeastern Illinois University (NEIU; Hispanic-serving institution), and GeoLatinas (Latinx-focused organization). This effort will build inclusive institutional structures that will provide sustainable pathways for Latinx students to enter graduate training in the geosciences, at MSU and beyond. This effort towards structural reform will enhance diversity through the promotion of inclusion, leading to retention at the graduate level and the establishment of support systems as students move into geoscience related careers.

Latinx students are severely underrepresented in geoscience. To this point, the project addresses four goals: 1. Recruit Latinx undergraduates from diverse sciences into geoscience graduate school; 2. Support socialization into graduate school and geoscience careers; 3. Mentor via routine on-the-ground and virtual interactions; and 4. Advance Latinx scholars as they enter and engage with the geoscience workforce. Activities are grounded in four stages of Graduate Student Socialization, plus a fifth Wellbeing stage. All three partner organizations will collaborate to meet these goals. Undergraduates/recent graduates from all sciences will be exposed to geoscience graduate opportunities through workshops at NEIU, graduate-like research experiences at MSU, and GeoLatinas virtual interactions focused on mentoring and professional and personal development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Earth and Environmental Sciences (EES) is, by nature, an interdisciplinary endeavor, combining physics, chemistry, biology, and engineering. Consequently, the career prospects for geoscientists span diverse areas in academia, industry, and government and range from the benchtop to the classroom, and beyond. This varied nature provides an opportunity to harness the diverse pathways intersecting with EES including the diverse array of human resources, knowledge, and perspectives needed to enhance the EES workforce. Given the lack of representation of Latinx/Hispanic students in EES, GeoCaFES (Communities and Future Earth Scientists) offered a summer bridge-to-graduate-school program to engage students in authentic research and community-based mentoring and support.

 

GeoCaFES is a collaboration between an R-1 University (MSU), a Hispanic Serving Institution (NEIU), and a non-profit organization (GeoLatinas). In its 2 years as a pilot program, GeoCaFES attracted over 400 applications from interns throughout the US. Eighteen interns engaged in virtual or in-person research experiences in fields ranging from seismology to mineralogy to geocognition. Students were mentored in independent research, built relationships with each other and mentors, presented at a local research symposium, and in some cases collaborated on a Photo Voice documentation of their experiences and/or presented at international and regional scientific conferences. In addition to research experience, interns also received mentoring and support for personal and professional development and will continue to receive support as they apply for graduate school and jobs. Follow-on surveys indicate several of the interns have continued towards geoscience careers or graduate school. Overall, the participants reported the internship was a positive experience by building self-confidence, developing their ability to work in teams, and enhancing their communications skills.

 

A central tenet of the GeoCaFES program is the concept of a “community” of future Earth Scientists, both locally within the research cohort and more broadly within professional networks. GeoCaFES provided mentor training and support for faculty and graduate students in EES, which helped to change perspectives and awareness about what mentoring is and how mentoring can enhance careers. This concept is carried forward through the development of sustainable institutional structures that provide mentoring and support for graduate students, including career panels, training in scientific writing, and exposure to disciplines outside of their primary research area. Our project sought to evaluate whether highlighting the interdisciplinary nature of EES, providing an authentic and supportive community structure, and emphasizing the necessity of collaborative work can serve to diversify graduate programs, as well as the geoscience workforce. Outcomes of this work are being used to create and share long term resources for the geoscience community, and to provide recommendations based upon our experiences.
